citeinfo.title: Geoindicators Data

citeinfo.origin: Please refer to Dataset Point of Contact.
citeinfo.title: Please refer to the Projects table in the Landscape Data Commons database.

descript.abstract: GeoIndicators contains summary indicators from the Line-point intercept, Gap intercept, Vegetation height, Soil stability, Interpreting Indicators of Rangeland Health. These indicators represent biological and physical components are often used as indicators of the functional status of ecological processes and site integrity. Reference(s): a) Herrick, J.E., J. Van Zee, S.E. McCord, J.W. Karl, E. Courtright, and L. Burkett. 2018. The Monitoring Manual for Grassland, Shrubland, and Savanna Ecosystems. USDA-ARS. b) Pellant, M., P. Shaver, D. Pyke, and J. E. Herrick. 2005. Interpreting Indicators of Rangeland Health, Version 4.0. Interagency Technical Reference. U.S. Department of Interior, Bureau of Land Management, Denver, CO.
descript.purpose: This dataset can and should be used as a communication tool across interest groups (i.e. scientists and land managers can translate the concept of rangeland health with the public) to identify any potential risks in degradation or where current resource problems may exist. This approach can also be implemented as a means to assist in choosing monitoring sites for various monitoring programs.

procstep.procdesc: Indicators were calculated using the terradactyl R package indicator functions. https://github.com/Landscape-Data-Commons/terradactyl.

attr.attrdef: Unique identifier for each plot-visit.
'Unique ID referring to the ecological site
The date that data were collected at the plot.
Unique identifier of the broader project under which data were collected.

The percent of ground, not covered by foliar or basal plants, rock fragments, biological crusts, or litter. For example, points with sagebrush over bare soil are not counted in this indicator, also points with rock as the soil surface code are not counted in this indicator. This indicator is derived from the Line-point Intercept method.
The percent total foliar cover of plants in the plot. This indicator is derived from the Line-point Intercept method.

The percent cover of total litter (first hit), both herbaceous and woody, in the plot, not including litter that has cover above it. For example, points with sagebrush over litter are not counted in this indicator. This indicator is derived from the Line-point Intercept method.

The percent cover (first hit) of rock (i.e., rock, boulder, cobble, gravel, bedrock, and stone) in the plot, not including rock that has cover above it. For example, points with sagebrush over rock are not counted in this indicator. This indicator is derived from the Line-point Intercept method.

The percent cover of lichens (first hit) in the plot, not including lichens that have cover above them. For example, points with sagebrush over lichen are not counted in this indicator. This indicator is derived from the Line-point Intercept method.

The percent cover of cyanobacterial crust (first hit) in the plot, not including cyanobacterial crust that has cover above it. For example, points with sagebrush over biological crust are not counted in this indicator. This indicator is derived from the Line-point Intercept method.

The percent cover of mosses (first hit) in the plot, not including mosses that have cover above them. For example, points with sagebrush over moss are not counted in this indicator. This indicator is derived from the Line-point Intercept method.

Average height in cm of woody plants in the plot. This indicator is derived from the Vegetation Height method. Measurements will be dropped in any instance where a species was measured as a Woody height but the code in the species list is a Non-woody species. Heights where a species code was recorded but the height = 0 are not included in the height calculations.

Average height in cm of herbaceous plants in the plot. This indicator is derived from the Vegetation Height method. Measurements will be dropped in any instance where a species was measured as a Non-woody height but the code in the species list is a Woody species. Heights where a species code was recorded but the height = 0 are not included in the height calculations.
The percentage of the plot's soil surface covered by gaps between plant canopies that are from 25-50 cm in size. This indicator is derived from the Gap Intercept method.
The percentage of the plot's soil surface covered by gaps between plant canopies that are from 51-100 cm in size. This indicator is derived from the Gap Intercept method.
The percentage of the plot's soil surface covered by gaps between plant canopies that are from 101-200 cm in size. This indicator is derived from the Gap Intercept method.
The percentage of the plot's soil surface covered by gaps between plant canopies that are greater than 200 cm in size. This indicator is derived from the Gap Intercept method.

The average soil aggregate stability of all samples in the plot. This indicator is measured using the Soil Aggregate Stability method. In this test, stability ranges from 1-6, with 1 being the least stable and 6 being the most stable.

The average soil aggregate stability of samples collected under with cover (Canopy or Grass, Tree, Shrub, Forb, Root Mat) in the plot. This indicator is measured using the Soil Aggregate Stability method. In this test, stability ranges from 1-6, with 1 being the least stable and 6 being the most stable.

The average soil aggregate stability of samples collected between cover (e.g., with no cover directly above them) in the plot. This indicator is measured using the Soil Aggregate Stability method. In this test, stability ranges from 1-6, with 1 being the least stable and 6 being the most stable.
The latitude of the plot location in NAD83 datum. If Location Status = Private this is a fuzzed coordinate.
The longitude of the plot location in NAD83 datum. If LocationStatus = Private this is a fuzzed coordinate.
